title: Business & Technology:  Corporate Watch
text:
DOW

Earnings, Sales Rise

On Local Price Gains

Dow Inc. said its profit for the first quarter rose, driven by local price gains across all operating segments.

The Midland, Mich., materials company posted earnings of $991 million, up from $239 million in the year-earlier quarter. Sales jumped to $11.88 billion from $9.77 billion.

Local prices rose 19% from a year earlier, Dow said. "Despite supply constraints, we saw demand growth as the economic recovery continued to broaden, most notably in packaging, construction, mobility, electronics and consumer durables end-markets," Chairman and Chief Executive Jim Fitterling said.

-- Dave Sebastian

---

CLEVELAND-CLIFFS

Steel Firm Reports

First-Quarter Profit

Cleveland-Cliffs Inc. said it turned a profit for the first quarter as revenue rose.

The Cleveland steel company recorded earnings of $41 million, compared with a loss of $52 million in the year-ago quarter. Revenue shot up to $4.05 billion from $359 million.

Steelmaking revenue of $3.9 billion included $1.3 billion of sales to the automotive market, the company said.

Cleveland-Cliffs Chief Executive Lourenco Goncalves said the shutdown of auto plants because of chip shortages and other supply-chain disruptions aren't weighing on its steel shipments. The company raised a profitability metric for 2021 based on better-than-expected contractual renewals and the assumption that the U.S. hot-rolled coil index price averages $1,100 per net ton for the last nine months of the year.

-- Dave Sebastian

VALERO ENERGY

Texas Storm Added

$579 Million to Loss

Valero Energy Corp. said the major winter storm that hit Texas in February added more than $500 million in losses for the first quarter.

For the period, the Texas company lost $704 million, narrower than its year-earlier loss of $1.85 billion. "The operating loss in the first quarter of 2021 includes estimated excess energy costs of $579 million" tied to the Texas storm, Valero said. Revenue fell to $20.81 billion from $22.1 billion a year earlier. Refinery throughput volumes averaged 2.4 million barrels a day, lower than a year earlier.

Executives said Valero teams were able to safely shut facilities down amid the storm and resume operations after it passed.

-- Micah Maidenberg
